Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 40380 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
Support for the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-
Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation II 
(BIMSTEC – II)
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  BIMSTEC  –  Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and 
Economic Cooperation  
  BTILS  –  BIMSTEC Transport Infrastructure and Logistics Study 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Multisector (industry and trade sector development, and road 
transport) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Regional cooperation and integration (cross-border 
infrastructure); governance (public administration) [national, 
decentralized, and regional]; capacity development (institutional 
development)  
Location (impact)  –  Regional (high) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  S. H. Rahman, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  S. Bonu, Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division, 
SARD 
 
Team leader  C. M. Nguyen, Economist (Regional Cooperation), SARD 
Team member  T. Mirza, Young Professional (Economics), SARD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Over the last decade and particularly after the global financial and economic crisis in 
2008, the geo-economic landscape of the world economy has been rapidly changing. Asia has 
increasingly been assuming a larger role in the world economy. Regional cooperation and 
integration  in  Asia  is  on  the  rise,  and  Asian  countries  are  fostering  greater  and  more 
comprehensive economic partnerships with each other with the aim of reducing overreliance on 
developed markets for growth. It is against this changing economic landscape in Asia that 
member countries of the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic 
Cooperation (BIMSTEC)1 are actively accelerating cooperation in the BIMSTEC region.  
 
2.  In 2006, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided assistance for the preparation of 
the BIMSTEC Transport Infrastructure and Logistics Study (BTILS). In December 2009, the 12th 
BIMSTEC Ministerial Meeting endorsed the BTILS recommendations. Subsequently, in January 
2011,  with  the  goal  of  facilitating  cooperation  in  BIMSTEC,  the  13th  BIMSTEC  Ministerial 
Meeting agreed to establish the BIMSTEC Secretariat in Dhaka, Bangladesh, marking this as an 
important milestone in BIMSTEC cooperation. 
 
3.  The BIMSTEC Working Group at its meeting in Bangkok on 25 March 2011 requested 
ADB to provide support to implement the recommendations of the BTILS. Subsequently, ADB 
fielded a mission in May 2011 to Dhaka, Bangladesh and held consultations with the BIMSTEC 
Secretariat. The design and monitoring framework provides the expected impact, outcome, and 
outputs of the TA (Appendix 1).2 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The BIMSTEC countries have a combined population of about 1.4 billion, representing 
21% of the world population. The region, with its large population, high economic growth, and 
cumulative gross domestic product, has the potential to serve as a trading bridge between 
South and Southeast Asia. This potential has become more important with the recent global 
economic crisis, which hurt Asian economies, particularly exports. The collapse of demand from 
developed markets, among other factors, resulted in the deterioration of Asian exports. For 
example, from 2007 to 2008 exports of member countries of the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations (ASEAN) decreased by 17.48%; exports of member countries of the South Asian 
Association for Regional Cooperation decreased by 7.8%.3 
 
5.  Like other Asian countries, BIMSTEC countries have relied on developed markets for 
their exports. In 2007, for example, before the 2008 global crisis, 20.46% of Indian exports went 
to the European Union, 13.67% to the United States, and 2.21% to Japan. Similarly, 36.65% of 
total exports from Sri Lanka went to the European Union, while 25.82% went to the United 
States. The proportion of intra-trade among BIMSTEC countries was therefore very low at only 
7.64% of their total trade.4 
                                                
1 BIMSTEC was established in June 1997 as an interregional group to promote cross-border trade, 
investment, tourism, and technical cooperation within the region. Member countries include Bangladesh, 
Bhutan, India, Myanmar, Nepal, Sri Lanka, and Thailand. The participation of Myanmar in activities to be 
supported by this TA in other BIMSTEC countries may occur in accordance with ADB’s Myanmar 
strategy, March 2010, as amended from time to time.  
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 1 December 2011.  
3  International Monetary Fund. 2008. Directions of Trade Statistics. Dhaka. 
4  BIMSTEC Newsletter. January 2010. http://www.bimstec.org/Newsletter_XXIV.pdf

2     
6.  Asia, in general, and BIMSTEC countries, in particular, must diversify their sources of 
growth, including diverting trade from outside Asia to within Asia. However, Asian markets are 
fragmented. The fragmentation is exacerbated by various bilateral and multilateral preferential 
trading arrangements. Thus, Asia needs to focus its efforts on facilitating market integration 
within various subregional markets, such as ASEAN, BIMSTEC, the Greater Mekong Subregion, 
the Pacific Forum, and the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation; and use these as 
building  blocks  for  greater  pan-Asian  integration.  In  this  context,  BIMSTEC—as  the  only 
interregional mechanism between South and East Asia—is one of the most important regional 
mechanisms  to  help  transform  Asia  into  an  integrated  market  and  production  base.  For 
BIMSTEC to achieve this aim, it must consolidate and strengthen its institutional architecture. 
 
7.  At the request of the BIMSTEC countries, ADB helped prepare the BTILS report. The 
report  included  specific  recommendations  for  strengthening  the  institutional  structure  of 
BIMSTEC  to  expedite  regional  cooperation  in  transport  and  trade  facilitation.  The  12th 
Ministerial  Meeting  in  December  2009  endorsed  these  recommendations,  which  include 
establishing (i) a ministerial conference of relevant transport ministries for policy coordination 
and decision-making; (ii) a sector committee on transport and logistics at the  secretary or 
permanent secretary level; and (iii) five expert groups for subsector technical discussions and 
project implementation, preferably at the director general or joint secretary level. These expert 
groups  include  road  development,  railways,  maritime  transport,  aviation,  and  transport 
facilitation and logistics.  
 
8.  The  BIMSTEC  Working  Group  meeting  held  on  25  March  2011  requested  ADB 
assistance in enhancing BIMSTEC institutional arrangements through convening the sector 
committee on transport and meetings of expert groups. The sector committee can help with 
overall transport sector coordination. The five expert groups will coordinate, monitor, and review 
progress with project implementation in their sector, and report on implementation progress to 
the sector committee. This can help strengthen the coordination of projects and activities under 
the BIMSTEC Transport Cooperation Agenda, including the action plan and implementation 
program. To expedite the process, the BIMSTEC countries nominated members for the five 
expert groups in May 2011.    
 
9.  The 13th BIMSTEC Ministerial Meeting in January 2011 endorsed the establishment of 
the BIMSTEC Secretariat in Dhaka, Bangladesh. The secretariat will play a critical role in 
facilitating regional cooperation in BIMSTEC countries, especially in the areas of cross-border 
connectivity  and  trade.  The  countries  are  developing  specific  terms  of  reference  for  the 
secretariat.   
 
10.  The  TA  aims  to  strengthen  the  BIMSTEC  institutional  mechanism,  including  (i)  the 
BIMSTEC Secretariat, and (ii) the sector committee on transport and the expert groups. The TA 
is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 20205 and Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy 
(pillar on Regional and Subregional Cooperation Programs, and pillar on Trade and Investment 
Cooperation and Integration).6 The TA is included in the pipeline of the regional cooperation 
operations business plan for South Asia, 2012–2014.7   
 
                                                
5  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
6  ADB. 2006. Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2011. Regional Cooperation Operations Business Plan: South Asia, 2012–2014. Manila.

3 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The expected impact of the TA is enhanced regional cooperation and integration in the 
BIMSTEC region. 
 
12.  The expected outcome is an increase in the capacity of the BIMSTEC Secretariat and 
other BIMSTEC institutions, such as the sector committee on transport, the expert groups, and 
government  entities  in  member  countries.  This  will  be  accomplished  through  the  effective 
planning and implementation of regional cooperation activities. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA outputs are expected to help attain the desired impact and outcomes through 
various meetings of BIMSTEC expert groups, ministerial meetings, exchange visits, training 
courses, establishment of a BIMSTEC website, and preparation of policy papers.    
 
14.  The  expected  outputs  are  (i)  strengthened  BIMSTEC  regional  bodies,  and  
(ii) strengthened BIMSTEC Secretariat. Key activities to achieve the first output include updating 
of the BTILS, and organization of meetings of road, railways, maritime, aviation, and transport 
facilitation  and  logistics;  a  ministerial  conference  of  relevant  transport  ministries,  and  a 
BIMSTEC transport infrastructure finance conference. Key activities to support the achievement 
of  the  second  output  include  the  establishment  of  a  BIMSTEC  website  at  the  BIMSTEC 
Secretariat, visits to ADB headquarters, regional secretariats, and external training courses.  
ADB will organize all the activities. The design and monitoring framework describes the TA 
activities and estimated time frames (Appendix 1).     
 
15.  The TA will be successfully implemented with the assumption that BIMSTEC countries 
remain committed to pursuing BIMSTEC regional cooperation. Potential risks could include 
disagreements or disputes that may arise among member countries of BIMSTEC, and/or that 
government agencies concerned may be resistant to facilitating BIMSTEC cooperation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  It is proposed that ADB provide the equivalent of $750,000, on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The governments of member countries of the 
Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC) will 
provide logistic and administrative support (in kind) for BIMSTEC meetings and conferences 
organized in their countries. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented from February 2012 to July 2013. ADB will be the executing 
agency, in collaboration with the BIMSTEC Working Group and other BIMSTEC bodies, the 
BIMSTEC Secretariat, and relevant government agencies in BIMSTEC countries. A team of 
ADB staff from the South Asia Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division will 
be responsible for overall TA administration. The BIMSTEC Working Group, together with the 
BIMSTEC Secretariat will be the focal agencies for BIMSTEC countries. Disbursements under 
the TA will be made in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time).

4     
 
18.  The TA will require a total of 48 person-months of international and national consultancy 
services: 18 person-months of international services, and 30 person-months of national services. 
The international consultants will assist in reviewing and updating the BTILS, and undertake 
various  tasks  as  requested  by  the  BIMSTEC  Secretariat  and  BIMSTEC  Working  Group.  
National consultants will include a senior program analyst and a web designer. The analyst will 
be based at ADB headquarters to help implement the TA. A local web design specialist will be 
based in Dhaka, Bangladesh to support the BIMSTEC Secretariat in developing a website. ADB 
will engage the international and national consultants in accordance with the Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). All consultants will be recruited 
individually and selected on the basis of their qualifications for the assignment. The consultants 
will  work  on  an  intermittent  basis  (Appendix  3  provides  outline  terms  of  reference).  All 
procurement of goods or equipment, if any, will be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). For the workshops, and exchange visits, an 
advance  payment  facility  may  be  used  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).    
 
19.  The progress of TA implementation will be monitored through regular progress reports 
and  regular  consultation  meetings.  Outcome  evaluation  will  be  monitored  using  intended 
outcomes  and  outputs.  Lessons  identified,  research  papers  prepared  under  the  TA,  the 
progress report, and the outcome evaluation report will be disseminated through and shared 
with the BIMSTEC Working Group, BIMSTEC Secretariat, and relevant BIMSTEC sector bodies. 
Progress  reports  will  be  circulated  to  selected  stakeholders  and  posted  on  the  BIMSTEC 
website.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Support for the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation 
II (BIMSTEC – II), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Transport, trade facilitation, and regional cooperation consultants (international, 12 
person-months  combined,  on  an  intermittent  basis).  The  consultants  should  have  prior 
experience in working with South Asian countries in the areas of transport, trade facilitation, and 
regional  cooperation  with  at  least  10  years  of  working  experience.  A  master's  degree,  or 
equivalent, in transport, economics, and/or public policy preferably with specialization in the 
areas of transport, trade facilitation, regional cooperation, or other related fields is required.  
 
2.  The transport consultant will 
(i)  review and update the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and 
Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC) Transport Infrastructure and Logistics Study  
(April–October 2012); 
(ii)  prepare  required  research  papers  on  issues  related  to  transport  (March–
December 2012); 
(iii)  serve as resource person to prepare and make presentations at the following 
BIMSTEC meetings: 
(a)  April 2012: meeting of the expert group on road development (tentative 
venue: Bangkok); 
(b)  July  2012:  meeting  of  the  expert  group  on  railways  (tentative  venue: 
Dhaka); 
(c)  October  2012:  meeting  of  the  expert  group  on  maritime  transport 
(tentative venue:  New Delhi); 
(d)  April  2013:  meeting  of  the  expert  group  on  transport  facilitation  and 
logistics (tentative venue: Colombo); 
(e)  January 2013: meeting of the expert group on aviation; and 
(f)  July  2013:  ministerial  conference  of  relevant  transport  ministries,  and 
BIMSTEC transport infrastructure financing conference (tentative venue: 
Bangkok); and 
(iv)  perform other tasks as requested by the BIMSTEC Working Group and BIMSTEC 
Secretariat. 
 
3.  The trade facilitation consultant will 
(i)  review and update the BIMSTEC Transport Infrastructure and Logistics Study;   
(ii)  prepare required research papers on issues related to trade facilitation; 
(iii)  serve as resource person to prepare and make presentation at the following 
BIMSTEC meetings: 
(a)  April  2013:  meeting  of  the  expert  group  on  transport  facilitation  and 
logistics (tentative venue: Colombo); and 
(b)  July  2013:  ministerial  conference  of  relevant  transport  ministries,  and
